hedline.hl1: Corning Reportedly Will Buy Fiber Optic Division of Pirelli

abstract.p: Corning Inc, leading supplier of glass fiber, agrees to acquire fiber-optic telecommunications business of Pirelli SpA for about $3 billion (S)

block.p: Corning Inc., the leading supplier of glass fiber, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to acquire the fiber-optic telecommunications business of Pirelli S.p.A., the Italian tire and cable maker, for about $3 billion, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

Corning Inc., the leading supplier of glass fiber, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to acquire the fiber-optic telecommunications business of Pirelli S.p.A., the Italian tire and cable maker, for about $3 billion, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.
The sale comes amid mounting pressure to consolidate in the fiber-optic components industry after JDS Uniphase bought SDL for $41 billion in July, making it the leader in the field.
The deal helps round out Corning's product line and allows Pirelli to exit a highly competitive part of the fiber optics business that it has struggled in against much larger rivals.
The transaction will be all or mostly in cash, the executives said.

Shares of Pirelli and its parent companies, Pirelli & Company and Camfin S.p.A., were suspended yesterday in Italy because of speculation about an impending deal. News of a deal between Corning and Pirelli was reported on The Wall Street Journal Web site.

Corning, once known primarily for housewares, left that business three years ago to focus on high-technology businesses like photonics -- the lasers, amplifiers and filters that blast signals down the fiber optic pipelines of modern telecommunications.

Its entry may have been in glass fibers, but Corning has been on a buying spree lately, spending more than $6 billion on acquisitions in the last year as the company has become the leading supplier of optical amplifiers, cables and fibers.

At the end of July, Corning discussed acquiring the fiber optics business of Nortel Networks in a deal that could have been worth more than $100 billion. That deal was abandoned after the market pummeled shares of the companies.

Pirelli has also been on its own deal spree, selling its terrestrial optical systems unit and a 10 percent stake in its optical components and submarine optical systems units to Cisco Systems for $2.2 billion last year.
